OK <STUDENT> on the topic of climate change: what would you say are the main causes of global warming?

O2

Thanks <STUDENT> - a demanding question and you've given a very good answer! hold on
so i'l give you the three-word collocations for your ideas: melting ice caps and rising sea levels - what about one more? what about the weather?

ok, yes that's a good example - any other weather effects?

yes good one (well bad obviously!) thanks - if i say: drought/heatwaves/tornadoes/hurricanes - what kind of weather is that?
one word adjective!
disastrous?
yes it could be! i.e. if it caused a problem (of course it often does) - but a more 'neutral' word I guess is 'extreme''
Do you say them as 'extreme weather', right?
Absolutely yes the two words together: so, the three collocations for the consequences are; rising sea levels/melting ice caps and extreme weather - last category: what about the solutions?!
It's reducing CO2 emissions. For example, using solar/wind energy instead of fossil fuels.
yes fantastic - so one answer is to 'reduce carbon emissions' (Collocation!) - what kind of energy is e.g. solar/wind
Ah, sorry. Carbon emissions... Solar/wind energy is alternative energy.

Thanks <STUDENT> - yes, alternative sources of energy is definitely possible to say - can i give you the following collcoaiton for today: 'renewable energy sources' - also, don't worry, CO2 is correct too (in fact technically more correct I guess!) and common too...
I guess the scientific asnwers are clear enough - why do you think this might not happen?

I see. Yes, they are very useful especially when I watch News!

yes - they're definitely high-frequency this topic - I'm going to give you a quick practice OK?  maybe have a quick look back at them now and then I'll ask you a question and try not to look back but do it from memory OK?!

OK so use a two- or three-word collocation to replace some of the words in the following example! a. The most immediate danger for many coastal communities is that the level of the water is getting higher and higher every year
to replace the bit after 'communities...'
sea level rising
ok thanks - yes! but you'd have to say : the danger is that sea levels are rising (which is fine!)  - here we could also just say the danger is rising sea levels
can you say 'increasing sea levels' do you think?
I don't think so. Increase cannot be used to refer to higer level.
OK thanks - you're right i.e. we don't really use it for sea levels (because the collocation is with 'rise') but we do use increase with some things i.e. increased heart rate
it's just a question of collocation you know?
Here's one more: Probably the most effective solution to global warming is to use types of energy that never run out, like solar power.
Probably the most effective solution to global warming is to use renewable energy source, like solar power.
ok great! sources in plural yes! One more: Awareness of the effects of global warming is increasing because of the really bad storms and hot summers many areas of the world experiencing.

great! Another one:The most important measure we can take is to stop releasing so much carbon dioxide into the atmosphere.

great yes! emissions in plural yes! Last one: It is impossible for one country, however powerful, to solve the problem of global warming. The only answer is for many major countries to talk to each other and find an answer together.

basically no!
